description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: Hungary introduced new regulations as of March 31, 2020, to punish the spread of false news that damages the government's defense against the spread of Covid-19 by imprisonment.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time)

description:
Hungary, March 12, 2020:
The Hungarian Government issues a decree which, among other things, states that:
- "students shall be prohibited from entering higher education institutions" (as per §4b of the source document)
- "no extraordinary break may be ordered in public education institutions by their heads, the local government clerk or the Educational Authority for the purpose of coordinated protection" (as per §4c of the source document)
- "the Language Learning Programme Abroad [Külföldi Nyelvtanulási Program] shall be suspended" (as per §4e of the source document)
- "school trips abroad are prohibited and any school trips abroad already booked must be cancelled" (as per $4f of the source document).
The policy doesn't mention an end date.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with no conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description:
Hungary, March 27, 2020:
The Ministry for Innovation and Technology asks the heads of higher education institutions to uphold the ban on entering universities and colleges of higher education, although the previous measure ensuring this has expired. "[S]tudents at universities and colleges will continue to be taught via distance teaching next week", the Ministry states.

description:
Hungary, March 27, 2020:
The Hungarian Government issues a decree which states that ongoing training courses shall be suspended for the duration of the state of emergency. During the duration of the state of emergency, vocational training may be organised exclusively in the form of distance learning or digital training, even if this is not otherwise permitted by law or other agreements. The organisation of vocational examinations shall be suspended indefinitely. There is no explicit end date.

description:
Hungary, April 2, 2020:
In addition to the ban on entering educational institutions (with the exception of childcare which is still available in small groups), implied by the nation-wide lockdown initiated on March 28:
- "for the purpose of coordinated protection, no extraordinary break may be ordered in public upbringing institutions by their heads, the local government clerk or the Educational Authority", as per § 6, section 3 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet" (exceptions are formulated in section 4)
- "the Foreign Language Learning Programme [Külföldi Nyelvtanulási Program] is suspended", as per § 6, section 6 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet"
- "school trips abroad are prohibited, and school trips abroad that have already been booked must be cancelled", as per § 6, section 7 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet".
The lockdown expires on April 11, 2020. The policies mentioned in "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet" have no explicit end date.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that, during a final examination for higher education students, it shall be ensured that no personal contact between the examinee and other persons is required, and a distance of at least 1.5 metres is maintained between persons. Also, there is now a two-person final examination committee instead of a three-person one, "'thus reducing the risk of spreading infection[s]', said [State Secretary] Tamás Schanda". The latter also applies to final examination committees for doctoral students provided that a final examination committee may not have less than 2 members here.
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that accredited language examination centres may offer computer-based (online) language examinations for the duration of the emergency. "'Of course we remain convinced that an adequate level of foreign language skills is of paramount importance. So we do not want to discourage anyone from learning languages and even taking exams. That is why we have made it possible for suitable language examination centres to offer online examinations', [the State Secretary] said".
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that students who have successfully passed their final examination by August 31, 2020, shall not be obliged to pass the language examination usually required as a prerequisite for the award of the diploma. "'One of the reasons for this is that in the current circumstances there is a significant shortage of examination opportunities, so we cannot expect everyone to meet these requirements. The other reason for our decision is that we need all well-qualified young people to re-launch the economy after the epidemic. The existence of a final exam is proof that someone has the right professional skills, so in exceptional circumstances we are waiving the language exam', the Secretary of State explained".
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that students who have started the examination for the Hungarian language proficiency certificate but have not completed it due to the emergency, will be issued a language examination certificate based on the results of the partial examinations. "The emergency situation created by the epidemic would also pose a huge problem for those who were about to complete or naturalise their language exams. 'We have decided that in their case, the partial results and the foreign exam should be accepted as complex language exams', the State Secretary explained".
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in the context of the 2020 general admission procedure for higher education institutions, applicants for military bachelor's degree courses are not required to submit a language certificate (B2) in order to get accepted. Applicants for military master's degree courses are not required to undergo a basic administrative examination. For military service, applicants are not required to undergo a physical fitness test (there will still be health and psychological fitness tests). The physical fitness test shall be carried out within 6 months after the end of the state of emergency. Applicants for law enforcement courses are now required to undergo pre-screening only (instead of an aptitude test). Within 6 months after the end of the state of emergency, compliance of the admitted students with the usual eligibility requirements shall be examined.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency does.

Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in the 2020 general admission procedure for higher education institutions, a career aptitude test may, in accordance with its purpose and content, be organised instead of the career aptitude orientation interview, as the former does not require personal contact with the candidate.
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in the context of the 2020 general admission procedure for higher education institutions, practical examinations, the Hungarian language aptitude test for non-Hungarian citizens, the oral aptitude test and the professional examination for admission to higher education shall be organised in such a way that no personal contact between the applicant and other persons is required. The fulfilment of the admission requirements set by the higher education institutions shall be organised in the same way.
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency.

description:
Hungary, April 2, 2020:
In addition to the ban on entering educational institutions (with the exception of childcare which is still available in small groups), implied by the nation-wide lockdown initiated on March 28:
- "for the purpose of coordinated protection, no extraordinary break may be ordered in public upbringing institutions by their heads, the local government clerk or the Educational Authority", as per § 6, section 3 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet" (exceptions are formulated in section 4)
- "the Foreign Language Learning Programme [Külföldi Nyelvtanulási Program] is suspended", as per § 6, section 6 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet"
- "school trips abroad are prohibited, and school trips abroad that have already been booked must be cancelled", as per § 6, section 7 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet".
The lockdown expires on April 11, 2020. The policies mentioned in "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet" have no explicit end date. UPDATE: From April 10, 2020, the nation-wide lockdown (meaning the ban on entering educational institutions) is extended indefinitely as long as the state of emergency remains in place.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, April 17, 2020:
The National Government declares that this year's school-leaving exams will be held under changed conditions and with several precautions. Between May 4 and 21, only written exams will be organised. The exams in the major subjects will start at 9 instead of 8 am in order to avoid that students travel at the same time as those leaving for work. There will be a maximum of ten students per classroom and a distance of at least 1,5 metres will be maintained. There will be compulsory disinfection in all buildings and, if required but not compulsory, students and teachers will be provided with masks. If necessary, any classroom of any public education institution will be used as a venue for examinations.
Furthermore, only five subjects will be subject to oral examinations: Cultural studies, biblical studies, Judaism, folk art and religious studies. Sports will have oral examinations only. Because of the current restrictions on mass gatherings, graduation ceremonies cannot be held.
The policy is a one-time measure.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Hungary, May 4, 2020:
The Hungarian National Government proceeds to implement a nation-wide lockdown and for this purpose closes all schools. Childcare is still available in small groups. Higher education institutions may be visited by students if the necessary conditions for maintaining the protective distance are provided for, as stated in Government Decree 168/2020. Additionally, Government Decree 81/2020 states that:
- "for the purpose of coordinated protection, no extraordinary break may be ordered in public upbringing institutions by their heads, the local government clerk or the Educational Authority", as per § 6, section 3 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet" (exceptions are formulated in section 4)
- "the Foreign Language Learning Programme [Külföldi Nyelvtanulási Program] is suspended", as per § 6, section 6 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet"
- "school trips abroad are prohibited, and school trips abroad that have already been booked must be cancelled", as per § 6, section 7 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet".
There is no explicit end date to these policies.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises)

description:
Hungary, April 2, 2020:
In addition to the ban on entering educational institutions (with the exception of childcare which is still available in small groups), implied by the nation-wide lockdown initiated on March 28:
- "for the purpose of coordinated protection, no extraordinary break may be ordered in public upbringing institutions by their heads, the local government clerk or the Educational Authority", as per § 6, section 3 of the source document "81/2020. description:
Hungary, May 12, 2020:
The Hungarian Government issues a decree which states that contact hour training and vocational/central module final examinations shall be suspended. For the duration of the state of emergency, vocational training and final module examinations may be organised primarily in the form of distance learning or digital training, even if this is not otherwise permitted by law or other agreements. Training and professional examinations which are necessary to avert or mitigate the consequences of an emergency as determined by the Operational Task Force for Coronavirus Epidemic Response may be held physically. According to §2, 1b, specific training which requires personal presence need not be held in a distance format. There is no explicit end date to this policy.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Partial remote/distance learning  (e.g. Teachers with certain health conditions can tele-teach)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Hungary, March 27, 2020:
The Hungarian Government issues a decree which states that ongoing training courses shall be suspended for the duration of the state of emergency. During the duration of the state of emergency, vocational training may be organised exclusively in the form of distance learning or digital training, even if this is not otherwise permitted by law or other agreements. The organisation of vocational examinations shall be suspended indefinitely. There is no explicit end date. UPDATE: From May 12, 2020, examinations may be organised in a distance form. Training and professional examinations which are necessary to avert or mitigate the consequences of an emergency as determined by the Operational Task Force for Coronavirus Epidemic Response may be held physically. According to §2, 1b, specific training which requires personal presence need not be held in a distance format.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Hungary, May 4, 2020:
The Hungarian National Government proceeds to implement a nation-wide lockdown and for this purpose closes all schools. Childcare is still available in small groups. Higher education institutions may be visited by students if the necessary conditions for maintaining the protective distance are provided for, as stated in Government Decree 168/2020. Additionally, Government Decree 81/2020 states that:
- "for the purpose of coordinated protection, no extraordinary break may be ordered in public upbringing institutions by their heads, the local government clerk or the Educational Authority", as per § 6, section 3 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet" (exceptions are formulated in section 4)
- "the Foreign Language Learning Programme [Külföldi Nyelvtanulási Program] is suspended", as per § 6, section 6 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet"
- "school trips abroad are prohibited, and school trips abroad that have already been booked must be cancelled", as per § 6, section 7 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet".
There is no explicit end date to these policies. UPDATE: From May 25, 2020, kindergartens and nurseries shall operate in the normal way before the emergency situation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Hungary, May 27, 2020:
The Hungarian Government issues a decree which states that contact hour training and vocational/final module examinations may be organised in compliance with the epidemiological rules. No person over 65 years of age may take part in contact hour training or in the work of the examination board, though. Training and examinations may still be organised and completed by distance learning, distance education or digital training. A distance/digital format is to be preferred if possible. There is no explicit end date to this policy.

description:
Hungary, May 12, 2020:
The Hungarian Government issues a decree which states that contact hour training and vocational/central module final examinations shall be suspended. For the duration of the state of emergency, vocational training and final module examinations may be organised primarily in the form of distance learning or digital training, even if this is not otherwise permitted by law or other agreements. Training and professional examinations which are necessary to avert or mitigate the consequences of an emergency as determined by the Operational Task Force for Coronavirus Epidemic Response may be held physically. According to §2, 1b, specific training which requires personal presence need not be held in a distance format. There is no explicit end date to this policy. UPDATE: From May 27, 2020, contact hour training and final module/vocational examinations may be organised in compliance with the epidemiological rules. No person over 65 years of age may take part in contact hour training or in the work of the examination board. Training may still be organised and completed by distance learning, distance education or digital training. A digital format is to be preferred.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Hungary, June 2, 2020:
The Hungarian National Government declares that all kindergartens and nurseries shall operate in the normal way before the emergency situation. As per § 1, section 3, kindergartens and crèches may close for a maximum of two weeks until 31 August 2020. As per § 3, children's and youth camps may be organised both as day care and overnight camps from June 16, 2020. Additionally, Government Decree 81/2020 states that, "for the purpose of coordinated protection, no extraordinary break may be ordered in public upbringing institutions by their heads, the local government clerk or the Educational Authority", as per § 6, section 3 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet". This policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends.

description:
Hungary, June 2, 2020:
The Hungarian National Government declares that schools may organize individual or small group sessions in their premises for the purpose of catching up pupils. Generally, schools shall continue to operate according to the digital extra-curricular work schedule from 2 June to 15 June, 2020. Between 2 June and 26 June, 2020, all primary and secondary schools shall organise the supervision of pupils. Institutional childcare shall be provided in schools until 26 June 2020. For unsupervised pupils, childcare shall be provided during the school holidays.

description:
Hungary, May 25, 2020:
The Hungarian National Government proceeds to implement a nation-wide lockdown and for this purpose closes all schools. Kindergartens and nurseries can operate in the normal way before the emergency situation. Higher education institutions may be visited by students if the necessary conditions for maintaining the protective distance are provided for, as stated in Government Decree 168/2020. Additionally, Government Decree 81/2020 states that:
- "for the purpose of coordinated protection, no extraordinary break may be ordered in public upbringing institutions by their heads, the local government clerk or the Educational Authority", as per § 6, section 3 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet" (exceptions are formulated in section 4)
- "the Foreign Language Learning Programme [Külföldi Nyelvtanulási Program] is suspended", as per § 6, section 6 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet"
- "school trips abroad are prohibited, and school trips abroad that have already been booked must be cancelled", as per § 6, section 7 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet".
There is no explicit end date to these policies. UPDATE: From June 2, 2020, pupils may enter school buildings for educational purposes in exceptional cases.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that, during a final examination for higher education students, it shall be ensured that no personal contact between the examinee and other persons is required, and a distance of at least 1.5 metres is maintained between persons. Also, there is now a two-person final examination committee instead of a three-person one, "'thus reducing the risk of spreading infection[s]', said [State Secretary] Tamás Schanda".
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency. UPDATE: The policy ended on June 17, 2020, as the state of emergency ended on that day.

Generally, schools shall continue to operate according to the digital extra-curricular work schedule from 2 June to 15 June, 2020. Between 2 June and 26 June, 2020, all primary and secondary schools shall organise the supervision of pupils. School meals shall be provided in schools until 26 June 2020. For unsupervised pupils, school meals shall be provided during the school holidays.
Additionally, Government Decree 81/2020 states that:
- "for the purpose of coordinated protection, no extraordinary break may be ordered in public upbringing institutions by their heads, the local government clerk or the Educational Authority", as per § 6, section 3 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet"
- "the Foreign Language Learning Programme [Külföldi Nyelvtanulási Program] is suspended", as per § 6, section 6 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet"
- "school trips abroad are prohibited, and school trips abroad that have already been booked must be cancelled", as per § 6, section 7 of the source document "81/2020. (IV. 1.) Korm. rendelet". UPDATE: This policy ended on June 17, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that students who have successfully passed their final examination by August 31, 2020, shall not be obliged to pass the language examination usually required as a prerequisite for the award of the diploma. "'One of the reasons for this is that in the current circumstances there is a significant shortage of examination opportunities, so we cannot expect everyone to meet these requirements. The other reason for our decision is that we need all well-qualified young people to re-launch the economy after the epidemic. The existence of a final exam is proof that someone has the right professional skills, so in exceptional circumstances we are waiving the language exam', the Secretary of State explained".
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency. UPDATE: The policy ended on June 17, 2020, as the state of emergency ended on that day.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that students who have started the examination for the Hungarian language proficiency certificate but have not completed it due to the emergency, will be issued a language examination certificate based on the results of the partial examinations. "'The emergency situation created by the epidemic would also pose a huge problem for those who were about to complete or naturalise their language exams', the State Secretary explained".
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency. UPDATE: The policy ended on June 17, 2020, as the state of emergency ended on that day.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that accredited language examination centres may offer computer-based (online) language examinations for the duration of the emergency. "'Of course we remain convinced that an adequate level of foreign language skills is of paramount importance. So we do not want to discourage anyone from learning languages and even taking exams. That is why we have made it possible for suitable language examination centres to offer online examinations', [the State Secretary] said".
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency. UPDATE: The policy ended on June 17, 2020, as the state of emergency ended on that day.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in the 2020 general admission procedure for higher education institutions, a career aptitude test may, in accordance with its purpose and content, be organised instead of the career aptitude orientation interview, as the former does not require personal contact with the candidate.
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency. UPDATE: The policy ended on June 17, 2020, as the state of emergency ended on that day.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in the context of the 2020 general admission procedure for higher education institutions, practical examinations, the Hungarian language aptitude test for non-Hungarian citizens, the oral aptitude test and the professional examination for admission to higher education shall be organised in such a way that no personal contact between the applicant and other persons is required. The fulfilment of the admission requirements set by the higher education institutions shall be organised in the same way.
The policy is slated to end alongside the state of emergency. UPDATE: The policy ended on June 17, 2020, as the state of emergency ended on that day.

description:
Hungary, April 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in the context of the 2020 general admission procedure for higher education institutions, applicants for military bachelor's degree courses are not required to submit a language certificate (B2) in order to get accepted. Applicants for military master's degree courses are not required to undergo a basic administrative examination. For military service, applicants are not required to undergo a physical fitness test (there will still be health and psychological fitness tests). The physical fitness test shall be carried out within 6 months after the end of the state of emergency. Applicants for law enforcement courses are now required to undergo pre-screening only (instead of an aptitude test). Within 6 months after the end of the state of emergency, compliance of the admitted students with the usual eligibility requirements shall be examined.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency does. UPDATE: The policy ended on June 17, 2020, as the state of emergency ended on that day.

description:
Hungary, October 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that, on arrival at a public education institution (mainly childcare facilities and schools), everyone shall submit to a body temperature check. Public education institutions may be entered by students or persons as per § 5, section 1, points a) to c) of Government Decree 431/2020 (teachers etc.) only if ones body temperature does not exceed the level specified by the national medical officer (37.8 degrees Celsius). Children or minor pupils whose body temperature is equal to or above the set limit shall be separated from other children or pupils and the parent or legal guardian be informed immediately. No persons other than those mentioned in § 5, section 1 of Government Decree 431/2020 may enter public education institutions, except for the case as subsequently outlined in section 2.
The policy's ending is indefinite.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

Hungary, November 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that institutions of higher education (universities) have to implement digital learning. The Minister responsible for higher education or the respective educational provider may grant a waiver from this measure.
The policy is slated to end on December 11, 2020.

description:
Hungary, November 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that day nurseries, kindergartens and primary schools until the 8th grade shall remain open. School classes from grade 9 are to be taught digitally. On arrival at an open public education institution (day nurseries, kindergartens and primary schools until the 8th grade), everyone shall submit to a body temperature check. Public education institutions may be entered by pupils of legal age or persons as per § 18, section 1, points a) to c) of Government Decree 484/2020 (teachers etc.) only if ones body temperature does not exceed the level specified by the national medical officer (37.8 degrees Celsius). Children or minor pupils whose body temperature is equal to or above the set limit shall be separated from other children or pupils and the parent or legal guardian be informed immediately. No persons other than those mentioned in § 18, section 1 of Government Decree 484/2020 may enter public education institutions, except for the case as subsequently outlined in section 2.
The policy is slated to end on December 11, 2020.

description:
Hungary, November 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that day nurseries, kindergartens and primary schools until the 8th grade shall remain open. School classes from grade 9 are to be taught digitally. On arrival at an open public education institution (day nurseries, kindergartens and primary schools until the 8th grade), everyone shall submit to a body temperature check. Public education institutions may be entered by pupils of legal age or persons as per § 18, section 1, points a) to c) of Government Decree 484/2020 (teachers etc.) only if ones body temperature does not exceed the level specified by the national medical officer (37.8 degrees Celsius). Children or minor pupils whose body temperature is equal to or above the set limit shall be separated from other children or pupils and the parent or legal guardian be informed immediately. No persons other than those mentioned in § 18, section 1 of Government Decree 484/2020 may enter public education institutions, except for the case as subsequently outlined in section 2.
The policy is slated to end on December 11, 2020. UPDATE: From January 9, 2021, this policy is extended until February 1, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Types of people on school premises are limited (e.g. no parents) ,Temperature Check,Special provisions exist for some students in a school  (e.g. students living with essential workers can attend school while others must stay home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Hungary, January 23, 2021:
The Ministry of Human Resources declares that the central written examinations for high school admission will be held in strict compliance with the proven epidemiological rules already used in the matriculation examinations. In view of the epidemic situation, the exams are being organised in 535 more locations than before. Only students wearing a mask and after having their body temperature measured are allowed to enter the institutions, and no more than 10 students are allowed in a room during the examination. Wearing a protective mask is compulsory for supervising teachers. The organisers should provide an adequate supply of hand sanitiser at each venue and the school districts should also provide protective gloves for teachers involved in the handling and correction of examination papers.
The policy is a one-time measure.

description:
Hungary, March 8, 2021:
The National Government declares that day nurseries and kindergartens shall remain open (however, for kindergartens, an extraordinary recess has been declared). All other public education institutions (mainly schools) are to implement digital learning/teaching. On arrival at an open public education institution (day nurseries, kindergartens), everyone shall submit to a body temperature check. Public education institutions may be entered by pupils of legal age or persons as per § 18, section 1, points a) to c) of Government Decree 484/2020 (teachers etc.) only if ones body temperature does not exceed the level specified by the national medical officer (37.8 degrees Celsius). Children or minor pupils whose body temperature is equal to or above the set limit shall be separated from other children or pupils and the parent or legal guardian be informed immediately. No persons other than those mentioned in § 18, section 1 of Government Decree 484/2020 may enter public education institutions, except for the case as subsequently outlined in section 2.
School closures are slated to end on April 7, 2021.
The remaining parts of the policy are slated to end on March 22, 2021.

description:
Hungary, March 8, 2021:
The National Government declares that day nurseries and kindergartens shall remain open (however, for kindergartens, an extraordinary recess has been declared). All other public education institutions (mainly schools) are to implement digital learning/teaching. On arrival at an open public education institution (day nurseries, kindergartens), everyone shall submit to a body temperature check. Public education institutions may be entered by pupils of legal age or persons as per § 18, section 1, points a) to c) of Government Decree 484/2020 (teachers etc.) only if ones body temperature does not exceed the level specified by the national medical officer (37.8 degrees Celsius). Children or minor pupils whose body temperature is equal to or above the set limit shall be separated from other children or pupils and the parent or legal guardian be informed immediately. No persons other than those mentioned in § 18, section 1 of Government Decree 484/2020 may enter public education institutions, except for the case as subsequently outlined in section 2.
School closures are slated to end on April 7, 2021.
The remaining parts of the policy are slated to end on March 22, 2021. UPDATE: From March 20, 2021, measures stated in Government Decree 484/2020 are extended until March 29, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Full remote/distance learning (e.g. All teachers must tele-teach.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Hungary, April 19, 2021:
The National Government declares that primary schools (grades 1 to 4) may operate regularly. Secondary schools (grades 5 to 8) may operate in a digital format only. Digital learning shall be discontinued from May 10, 2021.
On arrival at an open public education institution (day nurseries, kindergartens, primary schools), everyone shall submit to a body temperature check. Public education institutions may be entered by pupils of legal age or persons as per § 18, section 1, points a) to c) of Government Decree 484/2020 (teachers etc.) only if ones body temperature does not exceed the level specified by the national medical officer (37.8 degrees Celsius). Children or minor pupils whose body temperature is equal to or above the set limit shall be separated from other children or pupils and the parent or legal guardian be informed immediately. No persons other than those mentioned in § 18, section 1 of Government Decree 484/2020 may enter public education institutions, except for the case as subsequently outlined in section 2.
The latter parts of the policy have no explicit end date.

On arrival at an open public education institution (day nurseries, kindergartens, primary schools, secondary schools), everyone shall submit to a body temperature check. Public education institutions may be entered by pupils of legal age or persons as per § 18, section 1, points a) to c) of Government Decree 484/2020 (teachers etc.) only if ones body temperature does not exceed the level specified by the national medical officer (37.8 degrees Celsius). Children or minor pupils whose body temperature is equal to or above the set limit shall be separated from other children or pupils and the parent or legal guardian be informed immediately. No persons other than those mentioned in § 18, section 1 of Government Decree 484/2020 may enter public education institutions, except for the case as subsequently outlined in section 2.
The policy's ending is indefinite.

description:
Hungary, November 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that institutions of higher education (universities) have to implement digital learning. The Minister responsible for higher education or the respective educational provider may grant a waiver from this measure.
The policy is slated to end on December 11, 2020. UPDATE: From May 10, 2021, rectors of higher education institutions may on their own decide to organise on-site education, in particular practical training of students and knowledge assessment requiring the presence of students in accordance with study and examination regulations, however, being subject to the "necessary security measures" (not specified).

Hungary, April 19, 2021:
The National Government declares that primary schools (grades 1 to 4) may operate regularly. Secondary schools (grades 5 to 8) may operate in a digital format only. Digital learning shall be discontinued from May 10, 2021.
On arrival at an open public education institution (day nurseries, kindergartens, primary schools), everyone shall submit to a body temperature check. Children or minor pupils whose body temperature is equal to or above the set limit shall be separated from other children or pupils and the parent or legal guardian be informed immediately. No persons other than those mentioned in § 18, section 1 of Government Decree 484/2020 may enter public education institutions, except for the case as subsequently outlined in section 2.
The latter parts of the policy have no explicit end date. UPDATE: From May 10, 2021, secondary schools (grades 5 to 8) may also operate regularly.

description:
Hungary, June 3, 2020:
The National Government calls upon the Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade to ensure the provision of 267 000 000 000 forint to support research and development of vaccines, therapeutic drugs and diagnostic tools to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

description:
Hungary, November 12, 2020:
The National Government decides to simplify and speed up the regulatory procedure for the procurement and licensing of vaccines and effective antiviral medicines: The National Institute of Pharmacy and Food Safety may temporarily authorise the domestic use of a medicine authorised in a third country to prevent the spread of coronavirus, provided that the product is of good quality and the tests carried out show it to be effective. The authorisation will be granted for a fixed period of up to six months, which may be extended for a further period of up to six months in particularly justified cases. The policy is slated to end on February 8, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description:
Hungary, November 19, 2020:
Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade Péter Szijjártó declares that a sample of the vaccine produced in Russia has arrived in Budapest, and Hungarian experts can start studying the vaccine to make the most informed decision possible on its possible use and licensing.

description:
Hungary, November 26, 2020:
The Ministry of Interior publishes its plan for prioritising vaccination. Accordingly, health and social care workers will be the first to receive vaccination against SARS-CoV-2, followed by persons belonging to a risk group, critical infrastructure workers and all 18-59 year olds not in the other risk groups.

description:
Hungary started pre-registration for the coronavirus vaccine on Dec.08,2020.State Secretary Csaba Dömötör said those that pre-register will also get up-to-date information about the epidemic and about when they can expect to get vaccinated. He said medically vulnerable groups and those in front-line jobs will get priority in access to vaccination.
For the pre-registration the government set up the Website "/vakcinainfo.gov.hu/"

description:
Hungary, December 27/28, 2020:
Prime Minister Viktor Orbán announced on December 18 that a first round of vaccinations against the coronavirus will most likely begin on 27 or 28 December, with 35,000 people scheduled to be vaccinated. Health workers will be vaccinated first. The vaccination will be voluntary and free of charge. UPDATE: The vaccination of health workers already started on December 26, 2020.

description: Hungary's government has decided to introduce certificates of immunity from coronavirus for people who have been inoculated or recovered from Covid-19, the prime minister’s chief of staff said on Feb.11,2021. Gergely Gulyás said that the certificate would be issued to people who have received the second shot of the vaccine, and indicate the date of administering the second jab. Those recovered from Covid-19 will be issued a certificate indicating the date of their release from hospital or their first negative PCR after their infection, or the tenth day after their first positive PCR test result. The certificates would be provided free of charge.

description:
Hungary, January 28, 2021:
Prime Minister Viktor Orbán announced on December 18 that a first round of vaccinations against the coronavirus will most likely begin on 27 or 28 December (actually began on December 26). Health workers will be vaccinated first. The vaccination will be voluntary and free of charge. Vaccinations are distributed at 25 vaccination points in the country. From January 7, 2021, residents of nursing homes will also receive the vaccine. On January 28, 2021, it was announced that the next target group in the vaccination schedule will be the oldest people registered for vaccination. UPDATE: From April 25, 2021, anyone who has not yet been vaccinated and has a valid registration can book an appointment online for their vaccination. The Sinopharm vaccine will be used here. Vaccinations will be given at hospital vaccination points.

description:
Hungary started pre-registration for the coronavirus vaccine on Dec.08,2020.State Secretary Csaba Dömötör said those that pre-register will also get up-to-date information about the epidemic and about when they can expect to get vaccinated. He said medically vulnerable groups and those in front-line jobs will get priority in access to vaccination.
For the pre-registration the government set up the Website "/vakcinainfo.gov.hu/"
Update2: Registration for non-citizens, Hungarians living abroad, and repatriated Hungarians who do not yet have a TAJ(public health insurance) card opened on Tuesday. People wishing to be vaccinated can register on www.vakcinainfo.gov.hu. UPDATE: Originally only Hungarian citizens residing in Hungary were eligible for the Covid-Vaccine,as of Tuesday May.4,2021 Vaccination registration has opened to foreigners living in Hungary, ethnic Hungarians living in other countries, and recently repatriated Hungarians, the government’s information center announced. A Hungarian health (TAJ) card is not required.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties

description:
Hungary started pre-registration for the coronavirus vaccine on Dec.08,2020.State Secretary Csaba Dömötör said those that pre-register will also get up-to-date information about the epidemic and about when they can expect to get vaccinated. He said medically vulnerable groups and those in front-line jobs will get priority in access to vaccination.
For the pre-registration the government set up the Website "/vakcinainfo.gov.hu/"
Update: Starting with May.17, 2021 Hungarians living outside of Hungary can also register for the coronavirus vaccine in Hungary if they are unable to get vaccinated in the country where they reside. Under the government’s plan, they will also be entitled to receive a Hungarian immunity certificate once inoculated. UPDATE: Originally the registration for the Covid-Vaccine was only open for citizens living in Hungary, now it has been extended to all hungarian citizens living insied or outsied of Hungary. The only condition for the registration is a current adress in Hungary

description:
Hungary, March 10, 2020:
The (National) Government has suspended the issuance of visas to Iranians on the recommendation of the OT (Operatív Törzs). Iranian citizens whose visa has not yet been stamped may not enter Hungary. These measures are in place indefinitely. UPDATE: On March 12, 2020, this policy was replaced by an entry ban for travellers from Iran.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)

target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description:
Hungary, March 15, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from the territories of Italy, China, South Korea, Israel and Iran may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from the territory of these countries shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. EEA nationals as per § 8 of the source document shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals.
There are exceptions to these provisions.
No explicit end date is mentioned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
Hungary, April 2, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of the source document shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
As of April 16, this policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Hungary, April 2, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of the source document shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals.
There are various exceptions to this provision. 
As of April 16, this policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: From April 2, 2020, all border crossings on the Hungarian-Austrian border and the Balassagyarmat crossing between Slovakia and Hungary have been re-opened to commuters with jobs on either side of the border. At Balassagyarmat, crossing is only allowed to those with a residence within 30 km of the border. There are no such restrictions on the Austria-Hungary border.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Hungary, May 14, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of Government Decree 81/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. Austrian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of Austria at specific times.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends.

description:
Hungary, May 22, 2020:
The National Government declares that Slovak citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of the Slovak Republic if their stay in Hungary does not exceed 24 hours. These individuals shall be obliged to leave the territory of Hungary within 24 hours of entry. The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
Hungary, May 22, 2020:
The National Government declares that Hungarian and Austrian citizens arriving from the territory of Austria may enter Hungary if they can prove by a document in English or Hungarian, issued not more than 4 days prior to entry and containing the result of a molecular biological test, that no SARS-CoV-2 virus is currently detectable in their body. EEA nationals as per § 3 of the source document shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description:
Hungary, May 22, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of Government Decree 81/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. Austrian and Hungarian citizens arriving from the territory of Austria may enter Hungary if they can prove by a document in English or Hungarian, issued not more than 4 days prior to entry and containing the result of a molecular biological test, that no SARS-CoV-2 virus is currently detectable in their body. Romanian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of Romania provided they submit to a medical examination.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Hungary, May 14, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. Austrian and Hungarian citizens arriving from the territory of Austria may enter Hungary if they can prove by a document in English or Hungarian, issued not more than 4 days prior to entry and containing the result of a molecular biological test, that no SARS-CoV-2 virus is currently detectable in their body. Romanian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of Romania provided they submit to a medical examination.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: Government Decree 226/2020 declares that, from May 25, Serbian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of the Republic of Serbia without any restrictions.

description:
Hungary, May 25, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of Government Decree 81/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. Austrian and Hungarian citizens arriving from the territory of Austria may enter Hungary if they can prove with the result of a molecular biological test that no SARS-CoV-2 virus is currently detectable in their body. Romanian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of Romania provided they submit to a medical examination. Serbian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of the Republic of Serbia without any restrictions.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: § 3, section 2 of Government Decree 235/2020 states that, from May 27, 2020, "a Hungarian citizen may enter Hungary from the territory of the Republic of Austria if he/she can establish that the final destination of his/her departure was the Czech Republic and his/her stay there did not exceed 48 hours".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, May 30, 2020:
The National Government declares that Bulgarian citizens and Hungarian citizens arriving from the territory of Bulgaria may enter the territory of Hungary if they can prove with reasonable grounds, in particular by presenting an invitation letter, official passport or work contract, that the purpose of their stay in the territory of Hungary is (a) the performance of official duties, (b) to participate in the activities of an international organisation, (c) a business trip, (d) humanitarian activities, or (e) visiting a relative. Hungarian citizens may enter the territory of Hungary from the territory of Romania if they can prove that the destination of their journey is Bulgaria for one of the purposes set out in points a) to e). EEA nationals as per § 4 of the source document shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Hungary, May 28, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of Government Decree 81/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. Austrian and Hungarian citizens arriving from the territory of Austria may enter Hungary if they can prove with the result of a PCR test that no SARS-CoV-2 virus is currently detectable in their body. Romanian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of Romania provided they submit to a medical examination. Serbian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from Serbia without any restrictions. Slovenian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from Slovenia without any restrictions.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: From May 30, 2020, Bulgarian citizens and Hungarian citizens arriving from the territory of Bulgaria may enter the territory of Hungary if they can prove with reasonable grounds, in particular by presenting an invitation letter, official passport or work contract, that the purpose of their stay in the territory of Hungary is (a) the performance of official duties, (b) to participate in the activities of an international organisation, (c) a business trip, (d) humanitarian activities, or (e) visiting a relative. Hungarian citizens may enter the territory of Hungary from the territory of Romania if they can prove that the destination of their journey is Bulgaria for one of the purposes set out in points a) to e).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, May 27, 2020:
The National Government declares that Hungarian and Austrian citizens arriving from the territory of Austria may enter Hungary if they can prove by a document in English or Hungarian, issued not more than 4 days prior to entry and containing the result of a molecular biological test, that no SARS-CoV-2 virus is currently detectable in their body. A Hungarian citizen may enter Hungary from the territory of the Republic of Austria if he/she can establish that the final destination of his/her departure was the Czech Republic and his/her stay there did not exceed 48 hours, as per § 3, section 2 of Government Decree 235/2020. EEA nationals as per § 3 of Government Decree 216/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: The policy was repealed on June 5, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Hungary, May 27, 2020:
The National Government declares that citizens from the Czech Republic and Slovakia may enter Hungary if their stay in Hungary does not exceed 48 hours. Czech and Slovak nationals residing in the territory of Hungary shall be obliged to leave the territory of Hungary within 48 hours of entry. Hungarian citizens may enter the territory of Hungary from the territory of the Czech Republic or the Slovak Republic if their stay in the Czech Republic or Slovakia has not exceeded 48 hours. EEA nationals as per § 4 of the source document shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: The policy was repealed on June 5, 2020.

description:
Hungary, May 28, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of Government Decree 81/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. Austrian and Hungarian citizens arriving from the territory of Austria may enter Hungary if they can prove with the result of a PCR test that no SARS-CoV-2 virus is currently detectable in their body. Romanian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of Romania provided they submit to a medical examination. Serbian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from Serbia without any restrictions. Slovenian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from Slovenia without any restrictions.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: From June 5, 2020, Austrian, Czech and Slovak citizens as well as Hungarian citizens arriving from these countries may enter the territory of Hungary without any restrictions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Hungary's borders remain closed, with the exception of Serbia, Romania and Slovakia, and the Czech Republic, with which it has reopened its borders as of May 27, 2020. description:
Hungary, June 12, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of Government Decree 81/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. Romanian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of Romania provided they submit to a medical examination. Croatian, German, Serbian, Slovenian, Austrian, Czech and Slovak citizens as well as Hungarian citizens arriving from these countries may enter the territory of Hungary without any restrictions.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, June 17, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of Government Decree 81/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. Romanian, Croatian, German, Serbian, Slovenian, Austrian, Czech and Slovak citizens as well as Hungarian citizens arriving from these countries may enter the territory of Hungary without any restrictions.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, April 2, 2020:
The National Government declares that health workers, soldiers, defence personnel, members of the professional service, employees under Act CXXII of 2010 and government officials under Act CXXV of 2018 may leave the territory of Hungary only with the special permission of the responsible Minister. The policy has no explicit end date. UPDATE: The policy ended on June 17, 2020.

description:
Hungary, June 12, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of Government Decree 81/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. Romanian and Hungarian citizens may enter Hungary from the territory of Romania provided they submit to a medical examination. Croatian, German, Serbian, Slovenian, Austrian, Czech and Slovak citizens as well as Hungarian citizens arriving from these countries may enter the territory of Hungary without any restrictions.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: Announced on June 16, 2020, and adopted on June 17, 2020, Romanian citizens as well as Hungarian citizens arriving from Romania may enter the territory of Hungary without any restrictions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Hungary, June 18, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian citizens arriving from abroad (with the exception of Hungarian citizens as well as EU/EEA nationals (plus citizens from Switzerland) and their family members - however, those from the UK are not exempted) for unofficial purposes are not allowed to enter the territory of Hungary through passenger transport. Those who, for example, work in the health care sector may be exempted if they can prove their respective purpose of entry by means of an application. Those applying have to undergo a medical examination for COVID-19 and are refused entry if they are suspected of having COVID-19. If the health examination does not reveal any suspicion of COVID-19, the person shall be placed in quarantine or in an official house quarantine designated by the epidemiological authority for 14 days. Serbia shall be the state eligible for entry on the basis of international reciprocity, as per § 1 of the source document "9/2020. (VI. 17.) KKM rendelet". Various exceptions are formulated. The policy has no explicit end date.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, June 18, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian citizens arriving from abroad (with the exception of Hungarian citizens as well as EU/EEA nationals (plus citizens from Switzerland) and their family members - however, those from the UK are not exempted) for unofficial purposes are not allowed to enter the territory of Hungary through passenger transport. Those who, for example, work in the health care sector may be exempted if they can prove their respective purpose of entry by means of an application. Those applying have to undergo a medical examination for COVID-19 and are refused entry if they are suspected of having COVID-19. If the health examination does not reveal any suspicion of COVID-19, the person shall be placed in quarantine or in an official house quarantine designated by the epidemiological authority for 14 days. Serbia shall be the state eligible for entry on the basis of international reciprocity, as per § 1 of the source document "9/2020. (VI. 17.) KKM rendelet". Various exceptions are formulated. The policy has no explicit end date.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, May 30, 2020:
The National Government declares that Bulgarian citizens and Hungarian citizens arriving from the territory of Bulgaria may enter the territory of Hungary if they can prove with reasonable grounds, in particular by presenting an invitation letter, official passport or work contract, that the purpose of their stay in the territory of Hungary is (a) the performance of official duties, (b) to participate in the activities of an international organisation, (c) a business trip, (d) humanitarian activities, or (e) visiting a relative. Hungarian citizens may enter the territory of Hungary from the territory of Romania if they can prove that the destination of their journey is Bulgaria for one of the purposes set out in points a) to e). EEA nationals as per § 4 of the source document shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: This policy ended on June 18, 2020, as the state of emergency was repealed on this day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description:
Hungary, June 17, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic may not enter the territory of Hungary. Hungarian nationals arriving from abroad through passenger traffic shall undergo a medical examination. Those Hungarian nationals who are not suspected of being infected with COVID-19 during a medical examination and do not reside in Hungary have to leave the territory of Hungary or are to be quarantined. A Hungarian citizen is regarded as non-infectious if it's proven that she/he has recovered from COVID-19 and shows no symptoms of infection, or has been under epidemiological surveillance for at least 14 days prior to entry, as per § 3, section 2 of the source document. EEA nationals as per § 7 of Government Decree 81/2020 shall be treated in the same way as Hungarian nationals. Romanian, Croatian, German, Serbian, Slovenian, Austrian, Czech and Slovak citizens as well as Hungarian citizens arriving from these countries may enter the territory of Hungary without any restrictions.
There are various exceptions to this provision.
The policy ends whenever the state of emergency ends. UPDATE: This policy ended on June 18, 2020, as the state of emergency was repealed on this day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Hungary, July 4, 2020:
The National Government declares that non-Hungarian citizens arriving from abroad (with the exception of Hungarian citizens as well as EU/EEA nationals (plus citizens from Switzerland) and their family members - however, those from the UK are not exempted) for unofficial purposes are not allowed to enter the territory of Hungary through passenger transport. Those who, for example, work in the health care sector may be exempted if they can prove their respective purpose of entry by means of an application. Those applying have to undergo a medical examination for COVID-19 and are refused entry if they are suspected of having COVID-19. If the health examination does not reveal any suspicion of COVID-19, the person shall be placed in quarantine or in an official house quarantine designated by the epidemiological authority for 14 days. Non-Hungarian citizens arriving from abroad may enter the territory of Hungary if they are entitled to reside in the territory of Hungary and present a document to this effect upon entry. These individuals are not to be quarantined if they submit a document in Hungarian or English containing the results of a molecular biological test carried out on two occasions within 5 days prior to entry into Hungary showing that no SARS-CoV-2 virus is currently detectable in their body. Various exceptions are formulated. The policy has no explicit end date.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, July 15, 2020:
The National Government classifies countries into different categories. Hungarian citizens and family members of Hungarian citizens who are not Hungarian citizens entering Hungary from a green country may enter Hungary without any restrictions. The same individuals entering Hungary from a red or yellow country shall be subject to a medical examination upon arrival. Non-Hungarian citizens arriving from a green country may enter Hungary without any restrictions. Non-Hungarian citizens arriving from a yellow country shall be subject to a medical examination upon arrival. If the health examination reveals a suspicion of infection, individuals shall not be allowed to enter the territory of Hungary. Depending on the result of the medical examination, individuals may be placed in quarantine for 14 days. They need not be quarantined if submitting a negative PCR test result prior to entry. Non-Hungarian citizens arriving from a red country may not enter Hungary.
The list of countries classified as green, yellow or red can be found in the document "Közlemény a COVID-19...".
Various exceptions to these provisions exist. Those who may be exempted for reasons such as attendance at family events have to undergo an application procedure where they can prove their purpose of entry.
No explicit end date is mentioned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, July 16, 2020:
The National Government classifies countries (as of July 16, including their administrative regions) into different categories. Hungarian citizens and family members of Hungarian citizens who are not Hungarian citizens entering Hungary from a green country may enter Hungary without any restrictions. The same individuals entering Hungary from a red or yellow country shall be subject to a medical examination upon arrival. Non-Hungarian citizens arriving from a green country may enter Hungary without any restrictions. Non-Hungarian citizens arriving from a yellow country shall be subject to a medical examination upon arrival. If the health examination reveals a suspicion of infection, individuals shall not be allowed to enter the territory of Hungary. Depending on the result of the medical examination, individuals may be placed in quarantine for 14 days. They need not be quarantined if submitting a negative PCR test result prior to entry. Non-Hungarian citizens arriving from a red country may not enter Hungary.
The list of countries classified as green, yellow or red can be found in the document "Közlemény a COVID-19...".
Various exceptions to these provisions exist. Those who may be exempted for reasons such as attendance at family events have to undergo an application procedure where they can prove their purpose of entry.
No explicit end date is mentioned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Hungary, September 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that Hungarian citizens and family members of Hungarian citizens who are not Hungarian citizens entering Hungary from abroad have to undergo a medical examination upon entry. Depending on the results of the medical examination, these individuals shall be quarantined differently, as per § 2, section 2 and § 3 of Government Decree 408/2020. Non-Hungarian citizens may not enter the territory of Hungary. However, various exceptions exist. Those who may be exempted for reasons such as attendance at family events have to undergo an application procedure where they can prove their purpose of entry.
No explicit end date is mentioned.

Depending on the results of the medical examination, these individuals shall be quarantined differently, as per § 2, section 2 and § 3 of Government Decree 408/2020. Non-Hungarian citizens may not enter the territory of Hungary. However, various exceptions exist. Those who may be exempted for reasons such as attendance at family events have to undergo an application procedure where they can prove their purpose of entry.
No explicit end date is mentioned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
